Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: I was just about to greet the bride-to-be and her entourage, who had arrived early and were already fidgeting with nerves, when my phone buzzed. It was Mia, my oldest friend, her name flashing with a desperate text: “Can you hop on a quick video call? I’m lost with this furniture and need help.” I glanced at the bridal party, their anxious eyes darting around the salon, clearly expecting warmth and reassurance from me. But Mia’s message tugged at me—she’d just moved into her new place, and I’d promised I’d always be there for her, especially during tough moments like this. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: be the calming, professional hairdresser these women needed, or the loyal friend Mia counted on. I could feel the pressure mounting, my mind racing as I tried to figure out how to be both, knowing I couldn’t possibly give my best to either at the same time.
